column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Biggest yarding at this fortnightly Ballarat sale for some time with agents penning 548 head - the increase linked to deteriorating feed conditions in the area. Quality was very mixed with a lot of single animals of varied breeds and condition. The cow section did have some good beef females, including a line of 35 heavy Angus which is rarely seen at this market. The other notable element of the sale was a lot of bulls, including some lightweight rougher pens. The sale had a softer tone, matching what has happened across the industry more recently.

The best heavy grown steers sold to 286c/kg and grown heifers with weight to 278c/kg. Restockers paid to a top of 330c/kg for a couple of better bred young steers. As a rule the better presented young cattle sold above 250/kg while the lighter calves and bits and pieces had a wide range of 150c to 240c/kg depending on breed and quality.

The main pen of 35 heavy Angus cows sold at 232c/kg for a cheaper result than a fortnight ago but in-line with more recent markets. Any heavy beef cows offering buyers good fat cover and yield consistently made from 220c to 235c/kg. But buyers were quick to pull back prices for even modest declines in quality, and plainer cows were at 140c to 210c/kg .Very secondary cows down to 100c.  For a yarding this size there was a reasonable number of bulls, the best high yielding types above 1000kg to a top of 238c/kg. Other bulls mostly 150c to 210c/kg, with the most secondary down to 80c/kg.

Market reporter: Jenny Kelly
